cards.front: State the additive property of phasors.
cards.back: The sum of sinusoids of the same frequency can be found by adding their phasors: v₁ + v₂ ↔ V₁ + V₂. The result is another sinusoid of the same frequency.

cards.front: State the derivative property of phasors.
cards.back: Differentiating a sinusoid corresponds to multiplying its phasor by jω: dv/dt ↔ jωV. This scales the amplitude by ω and shifts phase by +90°.

cards.front: Why must all sinusoids have the same frequency for phasor addition to work?
cards.back: The method relies on factoring out a common e^(jωt). If frequencies differ, the time factors are different and cannot be combined into a single phasor.

cards.front: What form should you use when adding phasors?
cards.back: Rectangular form: add real parts and imaginary parts separately. Then convert the result to polar to find the amplitude and phase.

cards.front: What is the integration property in phasor domain?
cards.back: Integration corresponds to dividing by jω: ∫v·dt ↔ V/(jω). This divides amplitude by ω and shifts phase by -90°.

cards.front: What are the two geometric effects of multiplying a phasor by jω?
cards.back: 1) The magnitude is scaled by ω. 2) The phase is rotated by +90° (counterclockwise). This is why derivatives lead the original signal.

cards.front: What happens when you add two phasors of equal magnitude but 180° apart?
cards.back: They cancel completely — the sum is zero. This corresponds to destructive interference of two equal-amplitude, opposite-phase sinusoids.

cards.front: Describe the graphical (tip-to-tail) method for phasor addition.
cards.back: Place the tail of V₂ at the tip of V₁. The resultant is the arrow from the origin to the tip of V₂. This is identical to vector addition.

cards.front: How does the derivative property apply to the capacitor equation i = C·dv/dt?
cards.back: In phasor domain: I = C·jωV = jωCV. This shows the current leads the voltage by 90° for a capacitor.

cards.front: If V₁ = A∠0° and V₂ = A∠90°, what is V₁ + V₂?
cards.back: V₁ + V₂ = A + jA = A√2∠45°. Two equal-magnitude phasors 90° apart combine to give √2 times the original magnitude at 45°.
